text: An ancient house, standing lonely in the middle of a  deserted landscape in Northern Germany; lying there like sleeping giant under the starry sky. But something seems strange: All of the windows and doors have been nailed shut. Text chart: "1976" The headlights of a car pierce the darkness.  A car halts in the yard.  Three MEN step out.  One of them is wearing police uniform.  The men switch on their flashlights and  look around.
How long has the house already  been like this? KARL LINDNER, a keen police officer in his late thirties, approaches the entrance door.  He speaks in a calm, hoars voice.

No idea. I haven't seen them in  weeks.  Lindner makes himself a picture of the situation. He rings the doorbell.  Nothing stirs inside the house.   Then, he tries to get a look inside through one of the  nailed-shut windows. Through the cracks, he can barely make out a faint  pulsating light.
I haven't seen them in weeks. The three men exchange looks.   With a heavy heart, Lindner makes his decision:
We're going in. The third man fetches a crowbar and prepares to open the  door with it.

The house door breaks open with a loud crack. On the floor below the mail slot, there are piles of mail and unread newspapers which the door pushes out of the wa as it opens. The three men cautiously enter.  They look around.  The  hallway is as dark as night.  Lindner tries the light  switch - nothing.  The only light comes from a TV-set  running in the living room.
The three of them enter the living room.  Disgusted, the  first man holds a handkerchief to his mouth.

Pooh, what a stench... There is a massive armchair in the center of the room, in front of the television. - There seems to be someone  sitting in it.  In the darkness we cannot recognize who i is. Lindner carefully steps closer. The second man stops in front of a large, dark stain on t wall.  He touches it, draws back his hand and inspects it - blood. Lindner slowly walks around the armchair.

My God... Marlene...! During the next flicker of light from the television, we  recognize the corpse of a woman around forty years of age Suddenly, Lindner hears something behind him - breathing! He turns around. Indeed, hidden in the semi-darkness, there is the shadow a figure squatting on the floor.

Frank... Hell, what happened in  here? Lindner carefully approaches the figure. It is a man, FRANK KOSINSKI.  He looks scrawny, all skin  and bones, with a pale and hollow face. He doesn't pay the least attention to Lindner.  Mesmerize he just stares at the dead woman in the armchair. The "first man" follows the direction the man is looking and takes a careful look at the dead woman.  Something  seems to be irritating him.
Now that's really odd.
What?  What is it?
I'd say she drowned... Lindner leans over to the lethargic man in the shadows.
Frank...!? He gently touches his shoulder.  At the same moment,  Kosinski seems to snap out of it. He begins to scream in wild panic - loud, heartrending!

A photo montage of corpses, preserved in the swamps over  hundreds and thousands of years: children, old people,  warriors, farmers with hair stained red from the humin  acid, bony extremities and shriveled faces with skin that resembles an ancient landscape ...

head_text.subj: LANDSCAPE OF SWAMPS IN NORTHERN GERMANY

text: The structures of the corpses' skin fade into pictures of vast landscape of heaths, forests and moors. An expensive offroad vehicle is leading a sports car alon a deserted country road.  It's a wonderful late-summer's  day.  The two cars take a bend...

... into the driveway of the same old house.  It lies  peacefully in the afternoon sun.  The gravel crunches  underneath the tires. A large moving truck is already parked outside. Title chart: "23 years later"

Driving the Jeep is ELLEN STRAUB, an attractive, self- assured woman of approx. 30 years. Asleep on the passenger's seat beside her is her husband  MARTIN, who in no way resembles the clichГ© of the  successful author - he has a rather boyish charisma and i a bit too attractive. Ellen stops the car and takes out some house keys.  She  holds them right up to her sleeping husband's ear.  Then, she shakes them.  They tinkle.
(playful)
Sir, we have arrived at your  residence. Martin blinks and takes the keys.
Thank you, James. The two of them step out of the car.

Also getting out of their sports car are PAUL - a dynamic looking man in his mid-forties - and his wife CLAUDIA.   Despite their careful choice of casual dress, they still  look like the epitome of snobbish city people. They take a look around.  Time has left it's marks on the old house:  Like an enchanted castle, it is camouflaged i waist-high grass and wildly ranking shrubs. Paul and Claudia exchange skeptic looks.
Well, look here!
Ladies and gentlemen: The  "Straub country-residence".
It looks more like the "Straub  ruins".
Welcome to the far end of the  world. Ellen contradicts.
The lap of nature.  Where's  your famous optimism? Two REMOVAL MEN climb out of the truck.  One of them is  still chewing on his lunch. He points at his watch as he addresses Martin.
Lunch break is 'til one  o'clock.
(sarcastic)
Sure, take your time. (to Ellen)
They get a lunch break before  they even start working.   Cool job. Laughing, the four of them enter the house.

They step into the entrance area.  The golden sunlight  shines in stripes through the shutters.  The house is old monumental.  One senses the centuries.  A staircase leads upstairs, the rooms on the first floor  are the kitchen and living room.  A heavy wooden door ope to the cellar stairs.

The country residence offers  everything the doctor ordered  for a stressed author needs:  fresh air, clean water and -  most of all - absolute peace  and quiet. Paul walks upstairs.  The staircase creaks.
This wood is pretty decayed.   Hope I don't land a floor  lower.
Although it would give you a  perfect opportunity to visit  our new wine cellar.
How old is this shack, anyway?
Four hundred years.  Come on,  I'll give you a tour of the  museum... (blinking an eye at Martin
and Paul) ...while our husbands already  get to work.
Martin and Paul are lugging a heavy desk out of the truck As opposed to the two removal men, they are really workin hard.
Damn, this thing is heavy.  Where do you want to have it?
Tenth floor.
Very funny.
Sweating, Martin and Paul are trying to push the desk  through the narrow door to the study.  They are doing a  pretty awkward job of it. Martin's hand brushes the door frame - a splinter.
Shit! Martin draws back his hand.  He's hurt.
What's the matter? Martin presses a handkerchief on the wound and has a clos look at the door frame. It is totally splintered, as if someone had forcefully  broken the door open!
Look at this.  The lock is  totally demolished.
I guess someone lost their key.   You did get your tetanus shots,  I hope? Martin is still looking at the broken lock.
I mean, seriously: It is  strange, isn't it? Paul puts it off.  Only now does he have a better look  around the room.

So what if it is.  There hasn't  been anyone in this house for  at least ten years. The study is covered with dust, the walls are stained and full of cobwebs - blind, high arched windows.  Single  pieces of furniture that the previous owner left behind i this spacious room.
Twenty-three, to be exact.

I wonder how you guys figure on  renovating this whole place.   You can afford to spend some  money.  If I was you, I'd spare  myself all the hard work.   Besides, didn't you want to  start writing again? Martin suddenly seems lost in thought.
Yeah sure, I will. Give me a  little more time. Paul gives him a downcast look.

If you throw away your career,  that won't change anything  either.  Now don't get me  wrong, but I'm telling you this  as your friend:  Your last  books were awful.  The  publishing house isn't even  sure whether to extend your  contract. Martin takes the handkerchief from his wound and looks at it.
I don't care about my career  right now, Paul.  Ellen and I  need to get our minds on other  things, first.  After  everything we've been through.

Ellen is dragging a moving carton full of dishes into the kitchen.  It seems to be very heavy.  Claudia hooks up a  radio and switches it on.  We hear a cheerful oldie (Life could be a Dream).   The song seems to bring back memories to Ellen:  She star at the radio. (Transformation from radio to:)

Flashback: Ellen, Martin and their son THOMAS (8 years old) are join at the breakfast table.  The radio is on - it's playing t same tune. The little boy is totally absorbed with his Game-boy. Martin sets a bowl of cornflakes and fresh fruit on the  table.
Here, partner:  A breakfast for  champions. The little boy rolls his eyes and turns back to his Game- boy.
I can't right now!  I'm about  to break the high-score! Ellen gets into the discussion.

You do that.  But first, eat  your breakfast, Tommi. Now, Thomas reacts.  He puts the Game-boy on the table.   He continues the game with one hand, while he obediently  shovels the breakfast cereal into his mouth with the othe
Goes to show again who's in  command around here. Martin gives Ellen a playful pat on the behind and kisses her.
(joking)
Sometimes I get the feeling you  only love me for my body. Martin grins.
Why else?
Come on, say it.  You know... Martin seems to know exactly what Ellen wants to hear.

Oh no, not again.  I just said  it for you last week. For a moment, the two of them stop paying attention to  their son.  Suddenly, Thomas grabs his throat.  He  swallowed wrong.  He chokes without making a sound.
Say it anyway.  Come on, how  much do you love me?
(quotes)

"With you, my life began  and with you shall it end..." Ellen gives him her most beautiful smile.  Martin respond with a short kiss.   At the same time, they hear the Game-boy fall to the floo It immediately draws their attention to Thomas. The little boy is desperately gasping for air.  His face already starting to turn blue. Martin runs to him.
Tommi, what's the matter? He pats Thomas on the back, attempting to clear his throa
What is it?  What's wrong with  him? Thomas coughs, choking, but he can't get his throat clear Martin recognizes the situation.
(yells)

This is serious!  Quick, call  emergency! Ellen hurries to the phone. Martin realizes that hitting Thomas' back is not doing an good.  He uses his finger to try to get the swallowed pie out of his son's throat. For Thomas, it is a battle against death. Ellen has gotten through to the emergency line.  She spea into the phone with distress.

This is Straub.  You have to  come, fast!  My son, he  swallowed something... Quick,  he's choking to death... Martin's attempts at helping his son remain futile.  Thom is beginning to lose conscience. Martin sweeps the table free of dishes in a single move a lays the little boy down flat.  He reaches for a sharp  fruit knife. Ellen comes running.
What are you doing? Martin holds the tip of the knife to the boy's throat.   It's not easy, since his son is wildly kicking around  himself.
I have to cut his windpipe...
(horrified)
You're not a doctor, you'll  hurt him!
(screams)
What else should I do, damn it,  he's dying! Again, Martin prepares to cut - he holds the knife to the larynx.  The boy's movements grow weaker.
Too high, you're way too far  up... you have to cut here... She points at the spot below the larynx while holding her little son tight.
Ellen, move aside...

Oh God, Tommi... Martin prepares to cut, but he can't - his trembling hand refuses to move.  Endless seconds pass.  The voices blur, like in a dream.  The music playing on the radio seems to become louder and louder (Life could be a Dream).
What's the matter?  Come on,  cut... Martin looks up at his wife.  He can't do it.
Ellen!
Ellen starts.
Ellen, are you alright? Claudia has already started unpacking the carton. Ellen quickly switches the radio off.  She tries to act a if nothing happened.

I'm fine.  I was just  distracted for a moment. Claudia notices how upset her friend is and wants to put  her arm around Ellen's shoulder.   But just then, the removal men push their way past them  with a cupboard. Claudia drops the issue with a look of sympathy.
The old house is resting peacefully in the sunset.  The  last rays of sunlight paint the horizon orange.  Warm lig shines out through the windows of the house.

The four friends are joined at the dinner table,   surrounded by packing cartons.  Their shadows are  silhouetted outside the large window.  Behind them lie th vast, lonely moors. Martin opens himself a beer, raises it for a toast.
To our hard-working wives.
Don't rejoice too soon.  The  bill is already on it's way. They toast with their bottles.  Ellen takes herself a  cigarette.  Martin notices it with disapproval.
I still can't picture it: The  two of you as country folk.   I'm telling you, in six weeks  you'll be back in the city.

Hold it right there!  I hate to  play the big boss, but as  Martin's publisher I can only  say:  Make the best of the  peace and quiet, the fresh air  and all that - and write a new  masterpiece! Ellen gives Martin a skeptical look - the moment of silen is almost too long.
First things first.  Now it's  our turn - just the two of us. Martin's hand wanders over to Ellen's.  She reacts a bit  hesitantly at first, but then they hold each other tight.

Ellen is taking a shower, washing off the dirt from a har day's work. The bathroom fills with steam. Ellen turns off the water faucet and steps out of the  shower cabin.  She reaches for a towel and wraps it aroun herself. Something catches her eye in the fogged-up mirror.   There is a number, as if someone had used a finger to wri it into the moisture: "7". She wipes the mirror clean and looks at it.
The following day: A warm late-summer's morning.  The house stands lonely in the rays of the rising sun.  Occasional dew drops glitter in the grass.
Ellen is asleep in her bed, despite the sun shining right in her face. Martin enters the room with a tray loaded with breakfast  delicacies.  He holds it under Ellen's nose.
(acting gallant)
"Wake up, wake up, it's break  of day."  Paul and Claudia have  already left, you sleepyhead. Ellen hides under her blanket.  Martin sets down the tray
You're right.  Forget about  getting up.  We'll have  breakfast in bed. Ellen resurfaces with a grin.  She is still sleepy. Martin jumps into bed and crawls under the blanket.
How romantic! He playfully burrows around under the blanket, making sil grunting sounds. Ellen giggles.  Suddenly, Martin sticks his head out.
(laughing)
Stop that!
(with a grunting voice)
You'll never get away from me! He grabs her and pulls her under the blanket.  Ellen  screams, and laughs.

Martin is working at his computer.  Everything is still s up a bit provisionally.  Only Martin's novels have alread been sorted into a shelf, with 10 copies of "Cherry-red  Tears" in front. He is trying to write, but by the look on his face and hi hesitant typing, we can tell that it's obviously not goin so well. Ellen carefully approaches him from behind, hugs him and  gives him a kiss on the cheek.
So, how does it feel to be  kissed by two women?
They say it's fantastic.  At  least that's what I read in a  men's magazine.  So who are the  two lucky ones?
Me and the muse, of course.   How is your book coming along? He grins and takes her in his arms.
Oh, the muse... we're still  having our differences.  You  know how it is with women.
Well then, I guess I'd better  leave the two of you alone.   But don't forget... Martin finishes her thought.

... we wanted to take some time  out for ourselves.  I know.   And I'll only work a little  while, I promise. Just as Ellen prepares to leave, she catches sight of an  old photograph lying on top of one of the cartons.  She  picks it up and takes the dust off of it. Under the dust, she finds an old black and white picture a couple with very earnest looks.  The retouched, pitch- black eyes give the photo a somewhat eerie touch. All of a sudden, unexpectedly, the man on the photo turns his head. His dead eyes look straight at Ellen! Startled, she drops the picture to the floor. Martin spins around.
What's the matter? Ellen hesitantly picks up the picture and looks at it  again.  It was only her imagination.  It is a normal, old black and white photo.
(irritated)
Oh, nothing.  Where did this  picture come from? Martin turns back to his work.
I found it here.  It's kind of  creepy, don't you think? Ellen makes a face.
Yeah.  It is, kind of. She puts the picture back and leaves.

Ellen comes out of the kitchen and walks into the dark  living room.  She is carrying some sandwiches on a tray. The room is only lit by the flickering of the television  set.  A spooky atmosphere. In front of the TV is a large, old armchair (the same one from the opening sequence!).  Ellen frowns.  She slowly  walks closer to it.
Martin? Suddenly, Martin's voice comes from behind the armchair.
Damn! Martin pounds his flat hand against the television.  The  screen shows no image, only snow. Ellen sets down the tray.
What kind of a horrible thing  is that?
It still worked in town.
I mean the armchair!
Oh, that was upstairs.  A real  antiquity!  I think it's great. Ellen instinctively feels appalled by the old piece of  furniture.
I don't know. Martin is still fighting with the TV-set, trying to find channel.
Maybe the antenna's broken.
We're probably lucky that we  even have running water and  electricity!  Damned box! He hits the TV with his fist. Suddenly, everything is dark!
Hey... the fuse.
Oh, damnit! He looks for a flashlight and switches it on.
Do you know where fuse box is?
In the cellar, I think.   Wait, I'll take care of it. He leaves the room.
Martin opens the fuse box and shines inside with his  flashlight:  A moldy mess of half-corroded wires leading  into various ancient switches.  The entire construction  makes a dangerous impression.
(talking to himself)

God, look at that... The cellar seems even older than the house.  It is a larg cold sandstone catacomb.  Several pillars support the  ceiling.  The walls are clammy and cold. Martin is standing in the darkness.  Something approaches him from behind - slowly, threateningly. Martin is looking for the blown fuse. The thing comes closer.  Finally, it grabs him.
Boo! Martin spins around, startled.
Jesus Christ! Ellen laughs.
I wanted to know what's taking  you so long.  You've been down  here forever.   (looks around, shivering)

It sure is cold down here.  We  certainly won't be needing a  freezer. She catches sight of an old shelf loaded with all kinds o strange old junk.  The shelf looks old and rickety.  Elle shakes at it, testing its stability.
We'll sure be sorting a bunch  of this stuff out. Martin points to the fuse box.
Look at this!  We'll have to  fix the whole wiring.  This  stuff is dangerous as hell.
We'll call for someone from  town first thing in the  morning.
Are you crazy?  That costs a  fortune!
Do you have a better idea?
I'll do it myself.
You?
My father was an electrician.   Already forgot that?
My father was a pilot.  And do  I know how to fly? There's a lot more Ellen would like to say about this, bu she contends herself with a meaningful look.

Just do me a favor and don't  get yourself roasted! Martin fumbles with one of the bigger switches, finally  flips it to the other side.  Click!  The catacomb is lit: lonely 40-Watt lamp dangling from the ceiling casts a dim light. Martin gives Ellen a triumphant smile.

Ellen is leaning against the door frame, dreamily gazing  into the night.  She is smoking a joint. Martin steps up from behind and takes the hand-rolled  "cigarette" out of her hand with a swift move.  He tosses it away.
Hey, flower child, the sixties  are over.  And this stuff is  hazardous to your health.
Yes, daddy. She gives him a hasty kiss and walks to the car.
Where are you going?
Well, if you won't let me smoke  grass, then at least I'll go  get myself some cigarettes.  Ellen gets in the car and takes off. Martin contemplatively watches her go.
That stuff is gonna end up  killing you.

Ellen is behind the steering wheel.  She lights up a  cigarette as she drives down a lonely road.  There is a  small bridge in the distance. Ellen slows down.  She glances at a road sign. Suddenly, her eyes widen.  She takes a second look. The road sign clearly reads:  "You have 6 days to live" The shock hits her like a fist. It takes her a moment to react.  Then, she slams her foot on the brake pedal. The car halts with screeching tires.  Ellen shifts into  reverse gear and drives back.  She stops by the sign. She reads: "Max. 6 t. Agricultural vehicles pass" - a  perfectly normal sign. Ellen is confused.  How creepy.  She continues on her way feeling a bit sick to the stomach.
Ellen parks in front of the house and steps out of the ca She looks worn-out. Martin has piled up all of the old furniture from the  house.  Ellen walks over to him.
What are you doing?
Making our very own solstice  fire. A match lights up.  The stacked furniture quickly catches fire. Only now does Martin notice the state his wife is in.
Is everything alright?  Aren't  you feeling well?
I just had a really strange  experience. Martin gives her a questioning look.
On an ordinary traffic sign, I  read... Ellen interrupts her sentence.  She's just too embarrasse to say it.
Oh, nothing.  I guess I just  still haven't recovered as well  as I try to make everyone  believe. Martin puts his arm around her and holds her close.
Maybe I should talk to Dr. Roth  about it.
Hey, take your time.  You know  time heals better than any  shrink ever can. Arm in arm, Ellen and Martin stand by the burning pile of furniture, staring into the fire.
I have a funny feeling.  Do you  think we'll get over all that's  happened?
We just have to make a new  beginning.
Cherry-red Tears.
What?
Cherry-red Tears, your first  book.  I read it at least nine  times.  And then I found out  you were going to attend some  kind of book fair.
Not a book fair.  I was signing  autographs in a department  store.
I was so excited about meeting  you.  Again and again, I kept  getting in the back of the line  so I could be the last to talk  to you.
And two months later, we got  married.  And all because of  one sentence: (quotes)
"With you, my life began  and with you shall it end..." This sentence strikes a chord within Ellen.  It hardens h heart.
Don't say that.  Please. A short moment of silence.  Ellen's eyes well up with  tears.
I miss Tommi so much.
So do I, believe me.
Do you really think anything  can ever be like it was before?
Maybe different.  I don't know,  Ellen.
If we stand a chance at all,  it's only by sticking together. Martin gives her a tender kiss.  The fire casts a warming shine on the two of them and the old house - in the  loneliness of the moors.
Ellen is wearing a paint-stained flannel shirt. She is bu painting the kitchen walls. The RADIO is playing in the background.

"... a very special day today.   Exceptionally hot, even for  this time of year.  And all the  windows in my studio are  already wide open..." Ellen isn't paying much attention to the radio.  Suddenly the tone of the radiobroadcaster's voice gets a more  penetrating touch.

By the way, Ellen:  You have five days left to  live. Ellen freezes.  She turns pale. Then suddenly, a noise - someone is knocking on the windo Ellen spins around and, startled, tips over a bowl.  It  smashes on the floor. Standing by the open window is Karl Lindner, a total  stranger to Ellen. Obviously, he is much older now.  His face is caved in, h hair gray.  However, his pleasant demeanor has stayed the same. He realizes that he's startled her.
Oh, sorry.  I didn't mean to  scare you. For a moment, Ellen is at a loss for words.  She looks ba to the radio, where the normal program is being continued
"... and matching today's  weather it's time for some more  of the hottest music of the  North..." Ellen turns the radio off.
Hello.  Can I help you?
Does this dog here belong to  you? Sitting next to him is a large mixed-breed with friendly  eyes.
No, I've never seen him before.

You know, I saw him sitting  outside your gate...  Oh, I'm  sorry, I'm forgetting my  manners again!  I haven't even  introduced myself yet.  Hi, my  name's Lindner.  Karl Lindner. He offers her his hand through the window.
Ellen Straub.
It's a pleasure.  You're from  the city, right?
Do I look like it that much?
Village gossip.  You're a real  attraction here. Ellen is still shook up by the radio announcement, but  nevertheless tries to hold up a conversation.

You're from around here, aren't  you?  There's something I've  been wondering about the whole  time:  This house, why has it  been empty all these years?  I  mean, I doubt if it was the  price. Lindner suddenly turns evasive and cool.
I guess it's too lonely for  most folks. (glances at his watch)
It's time for me to get going.  It's been a pleasure meeting  you.
Wait, won't you join me for a  cup of coffee? He turns down the offer, a touch too vehemently.
No, thank you.  I need to get  back home.  My wife is waiting. He leaves.  Ellen contemplatively watches him go. Martin enters the kitchen and puts his arms around her.
Who was that?
Someone from the village. She turns around to face him.
Martin, there's something I...  uh... need to tell you about.
Martin is seated in the old armchair.  Ellen across from  him.  He is grinning.

Okay, now let me see if I've  got this straight.  First you  get warnings from a road sign  and then from the weather  forecast.  Which one of us two  was the author again? Ellen feels disappointed and misunderstood.
Martin, it's not funny!
You know, it's not always easy  for me, either.  But at least I  try not to give in to each and  every neurosis. Now he's got her angry.
Well, apparently it was a big  mistake to try talking to you.  Don't you remember what we  promised to each other?   Honesty - trust!

Come on, this isn't about  honesty.  You just need a good  night's sleep.  The way you  toss and turn all night, even I  hardly get any sleep. Ellen realizes there is no use in discussing this any  further.
Well, excuse me for having  bothered you with my problems. She leaves the living room and walks out on Martin.

Ellen is using a spatula to scratch the old-fashioned,  yellowed wallpaper off of the walls.  She is still upset, and really taking it out on the wallpaper. Martin comes walking up the steps.  He is carrying a plat full of small, deformed cakes.
For you. He holds out the plate to her.  Ellen throws a skeptical  look at the mishap pastry.  She won't be bribed this  easily.
Now, what did I do to deserve  this?
Come on, at least try one.  It  took me two hours to make  these. Ellen goes back to scratching off the wallpaper.  Martin  changes his tactic.

What I really meant to say was:  I'm sorry.  I'm a real bonehead  sometimes.  But it's just that  I'm worried about you.  I'm  afraid you might get carried  away with something like that. Ellen interrupts her work and takes one of the cakes.  Sh tastes it.
Tastes awful. She grins.  Martin returns a smile.
But baked with lots of love. Martin helps himself to a small cake, too.  He bites off piece, and makes a sour face.  Then, he takes Ellen's pie out of her hand.
I think I'd better get rid of  this.  After all, I don't want  to kill you. He turns to leave.
Martin... Martin stops at the bottom of the staircase.
...Maybe you're right and I  just need to get some sleep.   Don't worry.  I'll get settled  in sooner or later.
The farmhouse lies in the loneliness of a starless night. Silhouettes of gnarled trees reach for the sky like black claws.
It's dark.  An eerie silence fills the house. Suddenly, there is a CHILD'S VOICE calling in the distanc
Mommy...
Martin and Ellen are asleep in their bed.
Mommy! Ellen wakes up out of her light slumber.  She opens her  eyes and looks around, searching.
Tommi...? The voice clearly echoes through the house.  (It sounds  like Thomas' call before the accident.)
Mommy... Ellen silently sits up.  She is wide awake.  She tries to wake up Martin.
(whispering)
Martin... did you hear that? No chance - Martin only mumbles a few unintelligible word and continues to sleep. Ellen gets out of bed.
Almost mechanically, the child's calling repeats itself.
Mommy... Ellen carefully heads down the stairs, toward the entranc door.  The voice seems to be coming from outside. Ellen opens the door, frightened.

The pale moonlight dips the landscape into a ghostly  atmosphere. Ellen's eyes search through the darkness. There!  There is something in the distance.  A child!  Th child is standing in the tall grass, looking toward Ellen
Tommi? She cannot believe her eyes. It really is her little Thomas!  He smiles.  There is  something about the way he moves that makes it look as if he's floating.
(louder)

Tommi! The little boy laughs.  He turns around and runs away in  the grass; as if in play. Ellen snaps out of her stiffness and chases after him. The small figure slowly disappears in the increasingly ta grass.
Ellen is running farther and farther away from the house. She stops.

Tommi, wait! But the little boy keeps running further. Ellen follows him, but her path grows increasingly  toilsome.  Her feet sink deeper and deeper into the moor. Now, the child is out of sight. Ellen is devastated.  She trips and falls to the ground. The swamp encloses her.  Ellen fights against the marsh  that she is sinking into deeper and deeper. Suddenly, the little boy steps back out of the darkness. He stays a few feet away from Ellen.  He smiles as he  watches Ellen sink into the deadly swamp. With a sudden jerk, an unknown force pulls her down into  the moor.  She is swallowed by the earth.

Ellen abruptly wakes up from her NIGHTMARE! She looks around herself.  She is in her comfortable  bedroom flooded with the warm rays of the morning sun.   Martin's side of the bed is already empty. Then, she hesitates.  Something feels wrong.  Ellen throw back her sheets.  Horror - her bed is full of mud. Ellen wants to scream.  She barely manages to suppress it

Martin is sitting at his computer, busily typing.  He see to be making progress on his book. In the background, Ellen hurries past the study.  She is  carrying the dirty sheets under her arm.  Without looking up from the monitor, Martin calls through the open door:
So, did you sleep good?
(calling to Martin)
Yeah... I have to go to town. Ellen enters the kitchen.  She hastily stuffs the bed- sheets into the washing machine.
Is there anything you need? She turns the washing machine on and heads for the door.

Ellen is about to leave the house.  The door is already  open.  In the entrance area, she finds the dog (that  Lindner had previously discovered in their garden) sittin in front of the cellar door. Ellen pets him in passing.
(to the dog)
Hey, you're still here.  I  suppose you like it here with  us.
(calling from the study)
No, thanks.  I have everything  I need.  Drive safely, you  hear? Ellen is already out the door.  She pulls it shut behind  her.
A pleasantly decorated consulting room.  Standing by a  window is PROF. ULRICH ROTH (Professor of Psychiatry), a  distinguished man around 50 years of age.

You see, there are various  approaches to an explanation  for what you are currently  going through. Ellen is hunched in a chair opposite of him. Prof. Roth turns around to face her and takes a seat behi his desk.  The leather chair creaks.

One of the latest theories  claim that at certain  frequencies, air conditioners  create an oscillation that can,  in fact, cause hallucinations.   They may also be due to the  interior pressure of your eyes  and so on and so forth.   Personally I believe that all  of this is nonsense.  The loss  of a child is a traumatic  experience. Subconsciously, you  may still be blaming yourself  for it, and maybe now believe  that your son should punish  you... Ellen impatiently cuts him short.

Listen, it's one thing to have  a guilt complex. But I know the  difference between when I'm  overstrung and when I'm seeing  things that are simply not  there!  Besides, it only began  after we moved!
(hesitantly)
There is, of course, another  possible explanation which I  dearly hope is not the case. Lost in thought, Prof. Roth taps his pen on his desktop.
And that is?
A tumor - which could cause  pressure on certain parts of  the brain and, thus, influence  your perception. Ellen stares at him, shocked.
Just to be on the safe side, I  would like to have a few tests  done.
Ellen is lying on a stretcher, slowly being moved into th opening of the computer tomograph.  She is wearing a pale green hospital garment. The penetrating sound of the machines - technical coldnes

Blood is filled into a cannula. Ellen is sitting on a stretcher.  The NURSE pulls the  needle out of her arm. DR. SCHLETH, a man who makes a somewhat lethargic  impression, enters the room and fastens the tomograph sho in front of an illuminated surface on the wall.
Congratulations.  You are  definitely the healthiest  person I've had in CT for  years. Ellen heaves a sigh of relief.
Dr. Roth gave me these for you.   Three times a day, after meals. He hands her a box of tablets.
What is this?
Fluctin.  A pretty strong  antidepressive... If you asked  me, I'd try to do without them  first. He takes a look into her health records.
You come from Goldmoor? Ellen answers absent-mindedly.
We just moved there.
(by-the-way)
One time, when I was in  college, we examined a swamp  corpse in pathology.  They had  excavated it there. Now he has Ellen's attention.

Three or four thousand years  old.  But I didn't deal with  the subject any more than  necessary.  You know, I never  liked pathology.  Somehow, I  always felt it reduced humans  to something they are not. Suddenly, Dr. Schleth's beeper goes off.  He takes a quic glance at it and turns to leave.
Dr. Schleth. The doctor stops at the door.
What do you believe happens to  a human after he dies? The otherwise reserved Dr. Schleth suddenly seems very  human.
You mean, do I believe in  something like a soul? He smiles mischievously.
I haven't seen one on any of my  x-ray pictures, yet.  But then  again, what would x-rays know? He turns around and walks out.  Lost in thought, Ellen  watches him leave.
Ellen steers the car into the driveway and climbs out.  T dog runs to greet her, wagging its tail.  Ellen kneels do in front of the dog and pets it.
Hey, girl!  Here, I brought you  something. She takes a collar with a little bell on it out of her  purse and puts it around the dog's neck.
Now all we need is a name for  you.  How about Clara - okay,  then: Clara. She walks to the house door.  The dog follows her inside if it were the most natural thing to do.  The bell jingle
Ellen enters the hallway.  At the same time, Martin comes upstairs from the cellar.
Hi, love.  Trouble with the  fuses again? Martin locks the door behind him.

It's a real mess.  I think it'd  be better for you not to go  down there for a while.  It's  just too dangerous. He drops the key for the cellar into his pocket.  Ellen  watches this with irritation.  Martin's entire behavior  seems odd. Behind Ellen, the dog trots into the corridor.
Don't tell me you've made  friends with that wandering  flea circus?
Why not?  She can guard the  house.  By the way, I gave her  a name: Clara. She pets the dog, not noticing the frown on Martin's face
Where have you been all day?
I went to see Prof. Roth!  You  know, I had another one of  those dreams last night.  I saw  Tommi! Suddenly, the look on Martin's face softens again.  He  takes Ellen into his arms to comfort her.
Ellen... our Tommi is dead.   And there's nothing we can do  about it. Ellen rests her head against his shoulder.

You know, Martin, since we  moved to this house...  sometimes I just get the  feeling that the past is  catching up to us again... Martin interrupts her with unexpected ill temper and free himself from the hug.

Oh!  Now we're getting to the  point!  So all of a sudden,  it's the house.  Yesterday, it  was a road sign.  And the first  thing you do is go and run to  "Dr. Freud"!  He heads for the study, leaving Ellen behind.  Ellen call after him:
But that's not the point!   What if all these things are  somehow connected?
Oh, baloney.  You should just  hear yourself talk! He treads up the staircase.
I'll be in the study, just in  case you decide to get  reasonable, after all. Ellen watches him with consternation.  She goes into the  kitchen, worried.

Lost in thought, Ellen takes out a cup and pours herself cup of coffee from a thermos.  She takes the pills that she got from Dr. Schleth out of  her purse and studies them. She looks out through the window, at the dreamlike  landscape of the moors.  There is a warm evening breeze. Suddenly, Ellen's eyes focus on the reflection of her fac in the window.  She faintly discerns something strange on her forehead: "4"! Startled, she touches her forehead.  There is nothing on  it. When she takes a second look at her reflection, everythin is normal again. The dog trots up to Ellen, whining balefully.
(to the dog)
Either Martin is right or I am  really starting to lose my  mind... For a moment, she considers taking one of the tablets.  B then, she determinedly throws the whole package in the  trash can.
Ellen parks her car in the center of the nearby village. The small township is smothering in a humid summer's heat Ellen heads for a bookstore with Clara trotting in behind

Ellen enters the shop.  It is unusually dark and quiet in here.  She runs her fingers across the shelves, searching She passes by a stand with pocket books, also including  several copies of "Cherry-red Tears" next to Stephen King "Shining".  She stops for a moment.  Smiles. Then, she finds the department for books on psychology.   She pulls out a book titled "The Inner Child - The Ghosts of the Past".  Leafs through it.  She stops at a certain  page:
(quietly reads to herself)
"...certain places arouse  recollections and links within  us..." Suddenly, Ellen hears a voice behind her.
First buy it, then read it! Ellen looks up.  The sales lady is standing in front of  her:  a skinny woman with small eyes suspiciously beaming at Ellen.

Yes, of course... I'll take it. She places the book on the counter.  All of a sudden, the sales lady has turned into the world's most friendly  person.  Ellen follows her to the cash register and gives her the book. The sales lady skeptically eyes the psychology book while she notes the price. Ellen puts the money on the counter and turns to leave th store, when the sales lady speaks up again.
You're the wife of that author,  aren't you? Ellen turns back to face her.
Martin Straub, yes.
Used to write some nice books,  your husband.  But that last  one was awful.  A terrible  book.  Didn't sell, either. Ellen really can't think of an answer to that.
I read it - violent trash.  My  husband said so, too.
Well, I've got to get going...  'bye. Ellen walks out of the shop.  The sales lady keeps talkin Her eyes are cold.
(loud)
It's bad and it's violent.  I  don't like that kind of stuff.   Tell that to your husband.
Clara is still waiting in front of the bookstore when Ell comes back outside.
Come on, Clara.  Let's get out  of here. Just as she sets out for her car, she discovers Karl  Lindner and his wife.  He seems to want to pass by her  without saying hello.
Mr. Lindner! Lindner realizes he has no way out of this situation.
Oh, Mrs. Straub.  May I  introduce you to my wife?
Just call me Elisabeth. She seems like a truly honest person and very awake,  despite her advanced age.  Ellen shakes hands with her.
Ellen.
You're doing fine, aren't you?   I mean... the two of you alone  in that house, so far out in  the moor. Lindner nudges his wife with his elbow.
In the moor? What do you mean  by that? Mrs. Lindner wants to answer something, but her husband  heads her off.
Stop scaring people.  Let's go.   We need to be on our way.
Excuse us.  But do stop by for  a visit sometime!  You are  welcome anytime. Lindner manages a smile and leads his wife away by the ar
Have a nice day. As soon as they are out of hearing distance, Mrs. Lindner tells her husband with obvious anger:
(quiet, reproachfully)
You didn't tell her!
We should leave the past alone.
Well, it will never leave us  alone as long as you ignore it. Back to Ellen:  She watches the two of them go for a  moment.  Then, she gets into her car and drives off.

Martin is in the study, working at his computer.  He is i a writing frenzy, typing in the words like a madman.  Ell comes through the door.  She is carrying the book about  Goldmoor in her hand.  At first, Martin does not react to her.  He keeps on typing.
It seems to be going well for  you. Martin continues to type as he speaks.
Where have you been?
In the village.  Look what I  found. She opens the book to a certain page and holds it under h nose. Martin is annoyed for having to interrupt his work.
Psychology, huh?  So, what side  of the rainbow are we on today? Ellen points out a certain passage in the book.
(reads out loud)
"Events commonly interpreted as  haunting apparitions often  result from psychic  disharmonies or undigested  traumatic ordeals..."
(impatient)
Ellen, what are you trying to  prove, anyway?  That we've  created ourselves a ghost?   Come on! Ellen persistently tries to get through to him.
It's just a feeling.  Don't you  sense it, too?
What? What am I supposed to  sense?
The house - Tommi - something  just doesn't jive here... Suddenly, Martin's voice gets disproportionately loud.

Now you go starting that again.   We decided together, to build  up something new here.  I, for  my part, am working on it very  hard.  But oddly, you seem to  have changed your mind. Ellen wants to reply something but just then, the doorbel RINGS.
Who's that?
I haven't the slightest idea. When she sees that Martin does not intend to answer the  door, Ellen goes downstairs herself.
Ellen opens the door.  Standing in the doorway are Paul a Claudia, both in the best of moods.
Surprise! Ellen hugs them, her mind still halfway on Martin.
Well, this really is a  surprise!  Come on in! Martin comes downstairs.  He seems anything but pleased b the company. Paul gives him a jovial pat on the shoulder.
Hey, my man!  How's the  masterpiece coming along?
Not so bad, if I could get some  peace and quiet around here. Paul understands the side-swipe.
Hey, hey, hey!  Say no more  until you've seen what we  brought: He puts a wide grin on his face.  Ellen and Martin exchan quick looks.  Paul pulls something out from behind his  back.
Scrabble!
Martin looks annoyed.  The four friends are comfortably  seated around the living room table.  Each of them has a  glass of wine. While they play Scrabble, Paul tells a dirty story.

God, you should've seen him!   Elke Schneider enters the room  and storms up to him.  She is  tremendous.  Her breasts are so  big that just recently, there  was a discussion about whether  they should be given country  names of their own. Laughter all around the table. Martin is the only one who is not delighted.  But Ellen is clearly relieved by this  moment of normality in the house.
Paul, you and your stories...  I've really missed you! Claudia looks around the living room.  Apparently, she  likes what she's seeing.
I'm impressed!  You two have  really gotten quite a bit done,  already. The sack with the Scrabble-letters is passed on to Ellen. She reaches inside.

What do you think?  We worked  our fingers to the bone and  now, we're both about to have a  nervous breakdown. Ellen places the letters on the table in front of her and begins to shuffle them back and forth.

I really wouldn't have thought  you two could stand it out here  for this long.  To tell the  truth, we even have some bets  going with a couple of  people... But Ellen isn't paying attention to Claudia's words any  more.  Terrified, she stares at her Scrabble-stones, whic she has already put together.  The letters form the words
Everyone is waiting for her to make her turn.  Paul start nagging.
Well?  Are you going to play? Ellen feverishly gathers up her letter stones and throws  them back into the sack.  She shakes it with special  thoroughness and draws anew.
I pass. Paul is pleased.  He puts down his word.
Triple word score, that makes  72 points.  Now what do you say  to that, honey-bunny?
My hero. They kiss. Ellen lines up her newly drawn stones in front of herself again.  Martin watches her. Ellen cannot believe her eyes.  Again, her letter  combination spells out:
This time, the others notice the look on Ellen's face, to
Ellen, what's wrong? It takes Ellen a moment to answer.
I just got exactly the same  letters for the second time. She gives Martin a significant look and shows him her  letter-board.  This time, she has proof!
(sarcastically)
Oh, "three days".  A new  message! He turns to Paul and Claudia.

Because - you know - Ellen is  receiving messages from road  signs, radio broadcasters and  now from Scrabble game stones. He turns Ellen's letter-board around for the others to se Martin's reaction hits Ellen like a fist.  She feels  humiliated.  She is at a loss for words.
And the best part is:  She  thinks the messages are meant  to announce her death. (makes a "spooky" noise)
Hooooo... Claudia looks back and forth between Martin and Ellen.  S realizes how serious the situation is.  As opposed to Pau who pulls out a news ARTICLE.

Talk about spooky.  Martin, do  you remember that splintered  door to the study?  I guess  there was more to it than just  a lost key. The headline of the article reads: "Murder in Goldmoor -  Many questions remain unanswered".

Let me see that! Ellen takes the article.  The picture underneath shows Ka Lindner in police uniform, 23 years younger. Before she even has a chance to read the article, Martin  grabs the newspaper out of her hands. He crumples up the paper and angrily turns to Paul.
Just perfect, Paul!  Well done!   Can't you tell that my wife is  upset enough already?  And then  you come up with this kind of a  story?! Ellen has regained her composure.  She is still outraged.
What do you think you're doing,  anyway?  Now give me back that  article! Martin shows no sign of reaction.
Ellen, I just don't want you to  get upset for no reason. He tries to conciliate by putting his arm on her shoulder But Ellen shakes him off.
(sarcastic)
How thoughtful of you! An unpleasant moment of silence.  Ellen looks at Claudia  and Paul - she doesn't want to make a fool of herself.
Excuse me for a moment. She storms out of the room. Paul and Claudia both look a bit sheepish. Martin holds the article to a candle and burns it in an  ashtray.
She shouldn't be worrying about  this stuff.  Lately, she's been  acting strange enough already.
Ellen is standing in front of the house.  Lost in thought she takes a drag from her cigarette. Claudia comes out of the house and joins her.
What's this going on between  you two?
Oh, I don't know.  I was hoping  things would get better once we  moved.
But nothing got any better? Ellen's eyes wander over the vast landscape of moors whic the darkness of the night has transformed into a surreal  shadow painting.
Lately, Martin hasn't been his  normal self.  The work, the  relocation...

You have to give him some time,  Ellen.  He's under enormous  pressure right now.  He hasn't  written a single decent  sentence since the accident. Ellen takes a last long drag from her cigarette, throws i on the ground and puts it out with her foot.
Yes, I know.  I try my best.   It's just that... sometimes I  wonder if we made a mistake by  moving here.
Martin and Paul are still seated opposite each other.  A  strange atmosphere.  Paul is trying hard to keep up a  conversation.
So, work is going well, you  say? Martin makes a very calm impression.  In the background,  the dog is barking at the cellar door.
(calmly)
Yes.  Splendid.  I finally  found a story that's both:   thrilling and true to life. Now, Clara starts to bark at the cellar door.
I'm glad to hear that.  You  know... Martin has a sudden outburst and yells:
(to the dog)

head_text.subj: NOW SHUT UP, YOU STUPID BITCH

text: Paul is all confused now.  He throws a helpless look towa the entrance door.
You know, I think I have to get  up early in the morning.  We  ought to get going.
Clara is still barking at the cellar door.  Then, she  starts to claw at the crack below the door, as if she had discovered something behind it.
The next morning: The house is enclosed in a light curtain of early morning fog.  Everything seems oddly quiet.  Not a single bird is chirping. The calm before the storm.
Ellen wakes up out of her light sleep.  She looks around. Martin's side of the bed is empty and unused.  Martin did not spend the night by her side.
Ellen enters the kitchen in her bathrobe.  She puts on a  pot of coffee.  Martin comes in.

Hi, darling. Ellen turns around to face him.  She is terror-stricken. His hands are covered with blood.  He seems to be oblivio to it.  In the best of moods, he walks to the kitchen sin while he continues to speak.

At last, I'm back on top!   Seventy pages in one night!   I'd say that just about breaks  the record... He starts washing his hands with meticulous care.  The re stained water runs into the drain. Ellen closes her eyes and fights the panic welling up  inside of her.

Ellen?  Is everything alright? She opens her eyes again.  She takes a second look and se that what she thought to be blood is only wall paint.  Sh discovers a bucket with a paintbrush beside the kitchen  door. She tries to conceal her thoughts.
Oh, sure.  I'm just a little...  dizzy. She hastily grabs the dog's food dish and fills it. -  Simply to be doing something; anything.
I ought to give Clara something  to eat. Ellen goes outside.
Ellen carries the dish outside and starts searching for  Clara.
Clara! Nothing stirs.

Come here, Clara!  I've got  something yummy for you. Then, she catches sight of something dark lying a bit awa in the grass. Ellen puts down the dog food and runs toward the spot. There, lying in the tall grass she finds the dog.  It's  dead!  It looks as if a wild animal had attacked Clara.
Oh, no! (loud)
Martin! She kneels down beside the animal's dead body.
(screams)
Martin! Martin comes out of the house and stops at the door.  He calm - too calm.
What?
Look at this!  The dog!  She's  dead! Martin shows no reaction.  He doesn't even seem to find i worth the trouble to go over to Ellen who is still kneeli in the grass.
She was old.
Old?!  Come look at this!  She  has wounds.  Wounds on her  head.  Like thrashes.  Or  bites.
Maybe an animal.
(furious)
An animal?  What kind of  animal?   A goddamned T-Rex, or what? Martin is still apathetically standing in the doorway.

She spent a couple of pleasant  days with us, and now she's  dead.  That's the way it is.   I'm sorry.  I have work to do. He goes back inside. Ellen watches him. This very instant, she realizes that this is not the man  she once married.  She knows that the time has come to ta up action.

A short distance away from the house, Ellen has buried th dog.  She sticks a small, self-built wooden crucifix into the soft earth. She stands there for a moment.  She looks over at the  house.  Silence.  Loneliness. Then, she hangs Clara's collar over the cross.  The littl bell jingles.
Ellen speeds down the country road in her car.  She passe the town sign of Goldmoor.  She has a tense look on her  face.

Ellen rings the doorbell. She is standing in front of Lindner's house.  While she  waits, she looks up and down the street.  There is no one in sight. The entire village seems deserted. Elisabeth Lindner opens the door.  She doesn't seem very  surprised to see Ellen.
Oh, Ellen!  I've been wondering  when you'd come.  Why don't you  step in.
Thank you. Ellen enters the house.
The hallway is dark.  The wood-paneled walls are decorate with pictures and certificates from Karl Lindner's years a police officer.
My husband is in his study in  the back. Mrs. Lindner leads Ellen through the corridor.
I really hate to bother him,  but...
Oh no, no.  You're not  bothering him. (she winks an eye)
He has lots of time since he's  been retired.

Ellen enters the spacious study.  Lindner is seated in  front of an easel, dexterously painting lines onto a  canvas.  He is working on a still life of flowers. Without turning around to Ellen, he says:
Come in. Ellen takes a look around the room.  It is also furnished in dark colors, and there are dozens of oil paintings  standing around the room.  Every single one a still life flowers.
You only draw flowers?  A  little unusual for a former  policeman. Lindner obstinately continues to work on his painting.

You know, after doing that job  for so many years, you learn to  appreciate the simple things in  life.  Flowers incorporate a  beauty that I always missed in  life.  But certainly, you're  not here to chat about my  hobbies.
1976.  What happened back then? With a heavy heart, he puts down his paintbrush and turns to face Ellen.
Do yourself a favor:  Don't  ask.

I appreciate your concern, but  we live in that house.  I need  to know what happened in there. Lindner turns back to his painting and continues to draw. He seems introverted, as if he were talking to himself.

We found the wife about a week  after she had died, hunched in  her TV-chair.  Her husband was  sitting in front of her; the  whole time, he sat in front of  her dead body.  A whole damn  week.  Her death certificate  says that she drowned, and her  husband was convicted, but God  alone knows what really  happened back then. Ellen is shocked.  Still, she persists.
What made him do it? Lindner doesn't answer.
That man, is he still alive?   Where is he?  Can I talk to  him? Lindner turns around to her again.  This time, he looks  determined.
Why don't you just leave the  past alone and now go - please. Ellen sees that it's no use.  She turns to leave.  But sh stops at the door and turns back once more.
If there's one thing I've  learned lately, it's that you  can not run away from the past.   Believe me. She leaves the old policeman behind.  Once alone, he lowe his eyes.
Ellen leaves the house, reflective.  Just as she heads  through the gate, Mrs. Lindner catches up with her.
Ellen!  Wait! She hands Ellen a small note.
Frank Kosinski.  Here's the  address.  Go see him.  Ask him.
Thank you.  Elisabeth, I didn't  mean to... Mrs. Lindner puts it off with a smile.
That's alright.  Don't  misunderstand my husband.  It's  only that he's already had  enough problems with this case. And who would believe him if he  told the truth?
But what is the truth?
I don't know all about what  happened back then.  But it  always stood between me and my  husband. Ellen nods and leaves.
Ellen parks her car in front of the large, old building. She opens the heavy double doors of the entrance.

A long, wood-paneled hallway with small resting areas.   Some of the elderly people are sitting around, others are playing cards or staring at a television - a strange  atmosphere. Ellen approaches a SOCIAL WORKER, who is pushing an OLD  LADY through the hallway in a wheelchair. The old lady giggles, as if she were mentally disoriented
Excuse me, I'm looking for  Frank Kosinski. The young man is of the silly, bored type.
Kosinski... (thinks for a moment)
Oh - you mean K.K.!
Sorry? The social worker grins.  He seems to think he's very  funny.
Killer-Kosinski, that's what  they call him around here.  He  did away with his wife. Now, the old lady joins in on the conversation.
I'm so glad you finally came.   We've all been waiting for you. She gently touches Ellen's hand. - The old lady seems to taking Ellen for someone else.
(softly, to the old lady)
You must be mistaking me. (to the young man)
Where can I find the man?
He's in the closed psychiatry.  This here's the open section.  Go down the hall, third door to  the left.
Thank you. The old lady keeps on persisting.

Are you doing better yet? Ellen is too preoccupied to worry about the old lady.  Sh leaves them with a quick nod and hurries on. The social worker starts pushing the wheelchair forward  again.  Walking away, Ellen still hears the old lady's  voice.
(to social worker)
Poor girl.  She only has two  more days to live, you know. Ellen stops.  She turns on her heels and runs back. She excitedly stops the wheelchair and leans over to the  old lady.
What was that?  What did you  say? The old lady doesn't seem to recognize her any more.
What do you want from me?
What you just said, about the  two days...
I didn't say anything! Ellen looks at the social worker, hoping that he might  help.
I didn't hear anything.  Sorry. Ellen doubtfully looks back and forth between the two of  them.
I'm sorry...  I guess I was  mistaken. She quickly turns her back to this embarrassing situation and leaves.
The MALE NURSE turns the key.  Before opening the heavy  door, he gives Ellen a questioning look.
He has his clear moments every  now and then.  But I wouldn't  get my hopes up high. They both enter the cell.

Frank Kosinski (approx. 70 years old now) is sitting at a desk.  He is busy putting newspaper articles into clear  plastic folders and carefully sorting them away. Ellen enters the room.  The nurse closes the door from  inside and stays standing next to it.   The room looks more like an office archive than the cell a closed psychiatric clinic.  There are several shelves  filled with neatly lined up files.
Mr. Kosinski? The old man takes no notice of her.  Ellen steps up to hi obviously feeling very uncomfortable about it.

Mr. Kosinski, my name is Ellen  Straub.  I live in your house  out in Goldmoor... I mean, the  house where you used to live.   There are a few questions I  would like to ask you. Kosinski does not react.  He seems so lost in his own wor that he hasn't even registered her presence.  He stubborn continues sorting his papers.

Mr. Kosinski!  Can you hear me? She waves her hand in front of his face.  No reaction. Ellen realizes that she'll have to come up with something else. She walks to one of the shelves and pulls out a file titl "1976".  Leafs through it.  She finds the article that Pa had brought the other night. She lays it on the desk, right in front of Kosinski's nos

1976 - What happened back then?   You... Now, she has his attention.  As if she had pushed the  button of a tape recorder, Kosinski immediately begins to recite the article.  He seems to know it by heart.

"October 4, 1976.  To this day,  the cold-blooded murder at the  remote homestead continues to  bring up questions.   Investigations have shown no  satisfactory results.  As was  announced by a police spokesman
Ellen gives the nurse a questioning look.
Never mind, it's his usual  number.

Yes.  That's right.  What  happened back then? Although Kosinski has the news article right in front of  him, he seems to be staring at the air.  Ellen tests him taking away the news report.  Kosinski continues to recit

"... another unsolved mystery  is the question, why doors and  windows had been nailed shut.   The murder suspect and only  witness is still in a state of  mental derangement. ..." Again, Ellen tries to interrupt him.
Okay, fine.  I read that.  It's  written in the article.  What I  want to know is:  What really  happened back then? Kosinski mechanically continues to speak.  Absolutely  inanimate.

"... Friends and family  describe him as a friendly,  reliable husband.  He had been  forced into closing his small  trades business after  bankruptcy.  It is uncertain  whether this might have been  cause for marital dispute..." Ellen realizes that she cannot get through to him with  words.  She finds a page on the desk that was torn out of chronicle about Goldmoor.
August 17, 1869.
"August 17, 1869.  A messenger  found Mr. and Mrs. Eugen and  Wilhelmine Meister dead in  their house."   With both astonishment and dismay, Ellen listens to the o man's monotonous lecture.
"...The police constable in  charge found no traces.  The  motive of the crime remains a  mystery..." Ellen turns to the nurse.
Could I please speak with him  alone for a moment?
Are you sure?
I'll be fine.  Thank you. The nurse leaves the cell with a frown. Ellen takes Kosinski's chair and turns him around.  She  looks straight into his blank eyes.

I am starting to get the  impression that all of this is  some kind of bad joke:  I'm  seeing things that are not  there, my own husband is  becoming a total stranger and  your old friend Lindner won't  tell me what he knows.  I have  no idea what you're trying to  prove with this performance of  yours, but I am not leaving  this room before I hear the  truth. No reaction.  Kosinski continues to stare at nothing in  particular.  Ellen gives up.  Shaking her head, she turns to the door.
It's a grave. Ellen freezes and looks back at Kosinski.  She walks back over to him.

What? Suddenly, Kosinski seems to have snapped out of his  "autism".  He is holding an old book in his hands.  The  book contains clippings, notes and among others, a page  that seems to have been torn out of another book. It is an etching from the Middle Ages illustrating a man  being pushed into the swamp by several villagers. Ellen reads the text underneath the illustration:
"...Execution in the moor..." All of a sudden, Kosinski grabs Ellen and pulls her close His eyes have a feverish glow.
The moor... it's one big grave.

Ellen enters the hallway.  She runs into Martin who is on his way up from the cellar. When he sees Ellen, he shuts the cellar door and puts the key into his pocket again.  It seems as if he felt caught doing something.
(sarcastic)
Let me guess:  Another short  circuit?
Hi, darling. Martin ignores her comment and starts to head up the stai to his study.
What is going on down there,  anyway?  Why am I not supposed  to go in the cellar? Martin stops at the base of the stairway.
I told you:  It's too  dangerous.  Besides, I have to  work now. He continues up the staircase.  Ellen follows him.
Martin, we need to talk.  I've  done some research.  This  lovely house of ours has a  history of murder cases. Martin does not stop walking, but his eyes show alarm.
Anyone who ever lived in this  house either quickly moved back  out, or fell victim to strange  accidents, or ended up killing  each other.
Martin sits down at his desk and immediately starts typin Ellen won't give up so easy.

I know you don't believe me,  but at least hear me out.   Don't tell me you haven't  noticed that we've been going  through some strange changes  since we moved here! We hardly talk to each other  any more, you're writing like a  madman and I'm having these  visions. Martin does not interrupt his work. Ellen slams the articles from Kosinski on his keyboard.

Here, look at this!  Did you  know that our house is built  right on a spot where during  the Middle Ages people were  executed?  They simply threw  the convicts into the moors,  alive. Martin shakes his head.  He smiles and shoves the article aside.
During the Middle Ages people  were executed at every corner.   What's your point?
This house, the whole damned  area around here is one mass  grave...  Now you might call me  crazy, but there is something  negative about the place.
Okay, so the house has a  history and there might still  be a couple of corpses in the  moors. (mocking)
"There is something negative  about the place..."  What the  hell are you trying to say?   Come on!  Spit it out! Ellen twists around.
It's like... a sickness!  And  it's gotten into our heads. Now Martin gets aggressive.

Will you finally cut it out?   Just in case you haven't  noticed, I am trying to write a  book here.  And maybe - even  with your birdbrains - you can  figure it's a pretty tough job. So why can't you just leave me  alone?
Damn it, look at you!  Don't  you see what's happening with  you?  We need to get out of  here, don't you understand?   Out of this house! Martin threatens her with his forefinger.
Now let me work! Martin continues to write.
(hollers)

To hell with your damned work! In a rash action, she suddenly pushes his computer monito off of the desk. Martin jumps up from his chair.  He grabs Ellen by the  throat and pushes her against the wall.  Throbbing veins his forehead.

Don't you dare... Ellen can hardly breathe.  She is about to choke.  Just i time, Martin lets go. Ellen slides to the floor and gasps for air. Martin doesn't seem to care.  He sets the monitor back on the table and gets back to work. Ellen is deeply shocked.  She drags herself out of the  room. Martin doesn't even deign to look up at her again.
The door to the study falls shut behind Ellen. Slowly, she sinks to her knees and starts to cry.   Hopelessness and despair.
(sobbing)

Martin... oh my God... what's  happening to us... The house is dead-silent.  Only the sound of Martin typin on his computer keyboard in his study. Suddenly, Ellen hears a noise - very quiet.  It is the  RINGING of a bell. Ellen looks up. There it is again, very clearly:  It's the bell on the  collar of the dead dog.
(quietly, to herself)
Clara...? She stands up and heads for the staircase.  Cautiously. A shadow rushes through the entrance hall - the shadow of dog. Ellen sneaks down the steps.  Her eyes scan the darkness.

Again, the BELL RINGING.  The shadow.  The animal seems t have run into the cellar. Now, Ellen notices that the door Martin had locked so  carefully earlier, is open. A dirty-yellow gleam shines into the hallway from below. Ellen looks up - Martin seems to be working:  His steady  typing resounds throughout the house. It takes Ellen all the courage she has, but finally she  makes herself go into the cellar...
Martin stops typing in mid-sentence.  He looks up.  There is a threatening gleam in his eyes...

Ellen carefully walks down the stairs to the cellar.  It' cold.  The single light bulb at the ceiling hardly sheds  any light.  An eerie and unsettling atmosphere. No sign of the dog. Ellen finds the fuse box.  No difference - the wires are  still hanging out of the wall, tangled up and rotten. All of a sudden, there is a voice coming from behind Elle

Mommy... Ellen spins around. There's something in the darkness - a figure:  Tommi! Ellen freezes.  Her eyes are glued to the little boy, who figure melts together with the shadows.  Like a tape  recording, he repeats:
Mommy... Ellen fights up against the image as if she knew that it only a lie.
No... The boy steps out of the shadow.
Mommy... Ellen backs off.
My son is dead... The little boy comes closer.  Now, he is standing right i front of Ellen.  He raises his hands as if he wanted to b hugged.  Again, his sad voice repeats:
Mommy! Finally, Ellen's heart wins over reason.  She falls to he knees and takes the boy into her arms.

My God, Tommi. Tears run down her cheeks.  She holds the child close.  B what she doesn't see: The boy's mean smile behind her bac Suddenly, there is a strange transformation:  Running  through Ellen's fingers - little at first, but then more  and more:  mud! Thomas' body has turned into liquid in her arms.  Ellen i devastated. Right before her eyes, the child dissolves into swamp mud It drains away and disappears in the floor. Time seems to stand still. Suddenly, Ellen is grabbed by the hair and torn around. It's Martin!  He stares at her resentfully.
Didn't I tell you not to go in  the cellar?! Ellen does not understand what's happening.
Martin, what-
It's simply too dangerous here!   But no, you always have to have  it your way. She tries to squirm out of his grip - but it's no use. Martin drags her up the stairs.
You know what I have to do now,   and believe me:  I don't enjoy  doing this.
Martin, damnit, what are you up  to?  Let go of me!
Martin mercilessly drags Ellen along behind him.
Of course you'll give me the  blame again.  Like back then.   Just a tiny cut and he could  still be alive today - isn't  that right, Ellen?
What are you talking about- Ellen tries to find a way to free herself.  But she hardl stands a chance against Martin's strength.

Enough of that!  I know what I  have to do now. Sliding by, Ellen bumps into a tool box.  She gets hold o a screwdriver.  Panic-stricken, she thrusts it in Martin's direction. A scream of pain.  He collapses.  Bleeds. Ellen tears herself loose and runs out of the house.

head_text.subj: IN FRONT OF THE HOUSE / CAR

text: Ellen races to the car and jumps in behind the steering  wheel. Martin staggers out in pursuit of her.  He is holding his stomach. Inside the car: Ellen hastily crams out the car key.  It slips out of her hand. Martin is coming closer. Inside the car: Ellen gropes around in the darkness, trying to find the  key. Martin has almost reached the car. Inside the car: At last, Ellen has the key.  She pushes it into the  ignition, turns it around.  The engine roars up. Ellen careens off in the car.  She brushes Martin.  He  spins away with a loud thud. The car speeds off.
Prof. Roth is in the middle of a conference with two  INTERNS. The door flies open.  Ellen storms into the room with tea in her eyes; she is totally frantic. Her appearance surprises him.
Mrs. Straub!
I've killed my husband!
What?
I think I've killed him.   Martin, my husband, I've killed  him!  That is, I'm not sure,  but... Prof. Roth immediately takes her arm and leads her to a  sofa.
Mrs. Straub!  Now calm down  first. Ellen is totally distraught.
(hectic, loud)
It all went so fast.  He was  out of his mind and then all of  sudden there was this  screwdriver.  I only wanted to  defend myself.  You have to  call the police...
We can do all of that later,  but first you need to calm  down. He stands up, fetches a glass of water and takes a tablet out of a package.
Here, take this. Ellen takes the pill without a moment's hesitation and  swallows it with a drink of water.
I... I don't know which part of  it all really happened... It's  all one big nightmare... Prof. Roth sees that she is not able to think clearly at  the moment.

You are going to sleep for a  little while, now.  And then,  we'll talk about it more calmly  and sift through all of this. The tablet quickly begins to show an effect.  In Ellen's  eyes, Prof. Roth's face gets blurry. One of the interns speaks up.
Should we inform the  authorities? Prof. Roth waves it off.

Before everyone gets all  nervous, why don't you call her  house.  Maybe that will clear  things up. Ellen only vaguely catches the last spoken sentences  through a curtain of haze.  Then, she loses conscience.
Ellen drowsily wakes up in a hospital room.  She takes a  careful look around herself.  The room is surprisingly ni and pleasantly furnished.
There is a lot going on in the hospital corridor.   MALE and FEMALE NURSES busily take care of their duties. A hand picks up a syringe and an ampoule from a trolley.
The door is opened. Ellen barely manages to lift her head in order to see who the visitor is. A man pulls a wheelchair inside with his back turned to  her, and closes the door.

Professor Roth? The man turns around: It's Martin! He is wearing his best suit.  He shows no signs of a woun Ellen wants to call for help, but Martin is already up ne to her and holds her mouth shut with his hand.
Hello, darling.  Are you  feeling better? He thrusts the syringe into her leg. Ellen desperately searches for the emergency button for t nurses' room.
(whispers)

Shh... everything will be fine.   Tomorrow, it will all be over.   Just don't try to fight it. Ellen has found the button, but the medication is faster: She doesn't have enough strength to push the button any  more. Her tired eyes blink and fall shut for a moment...

... Ellen's eyes slowly open again.  She wakes up to a lo HAMMERING noise. Only now does she realize that she is lying on the planki of her own bed, with her hands and feet roped tight.   Martin has put a gag in her mouth.  He is standing by the window, nailing several large boards in front of it.   He is so preoccupied with his work that he hasn't yet  noticed that Ellen is awake.  He quietly curses under his voice.

You stupid little bitch...   think you can toy around with  people any old way you like.   But not me, no. Ellen carefully tries to loosen the ropes.  The sound  catches Martin's attention.  He turns around to her.  He still holding a nail in the corner of his mouth.
(sweetly)
Oh sweetheart, you're awake  already? He takes the nail out of the corner of his mouth and open his suit jacket.  Underneath, we see his blood-soaked  shirt.  But he doesn't seem to feel any pain.

That really wasn't very nice of  you yesterday.  I always  thought you loved me.  You  know, I bet any other husband  would be pretty upset with you  now. He sits down on the bed next to her and begins to loosen  her gag.
But I believe in our  relationship.  What are such  trifles compared to that. He takes the gag out of her mouth.  Ellen's voice is  shaking.
Martin, for heaven's sake, tie  me loose! Martin seriously shakes his head.
Believe me, I'd really like to.   But I have the feeling you're  not ready yet. Ellen lies there, totally helpless.
Ready?  For what?  This is  crazy!  Don't you see what's  going on here? He moves closer to her, caresses her cheek.
The last day, Ellen.  Today is  the last day.  The circle is  closing. Ellen suddenly understands.
You knew! Martin slowly leans over and kisses her.  Ellen tries to  turn her head away, but Martin holds it tight.  Barbaric there is nothing tender about this kiss.
Oh, Ellen.  My sweet Ellen...  Of course I knew.
We loved each other once.  Have  you forgotten that? Martin seems bitter.
Oh, yeah?  Did we really?   Think about it, Ellen... Just then, the DOORBELL rings.  They both look toward the door. Quick as a flash, Martin presses his hand on Ellen's mout so she cannot scream.
Are you expecting company?
Karl Lindner is standing at the door.  He presses the  doorbell button.  He is carrying one of his flower  paintings under his arm.
Martin puts the gag back into Ellen's mouth.
Make yourself comfortable.   I'll be right back. He stands up and leaves the room. Ellen hears him lock the door from outside.  She  immediately begins to tear at her ropes.

The doorbell RINGS again.  While Martin runs downstairs, buttons up his suit jacket again in order to conceal the  blood stains. He is still holding the hammer in his hand. He walks to the door and opens it to Lindner.
Good evening.  Karl Lindner.   I'm a friend of your wife.  Is  she in?

Ellen is still tied to the bed.  She faintly hears the tw men's VOICES from downstairs. She moves her head, trying to get rid of the gag - in vai Ellen screams, but only muffled sounds come out. She doubles her efforts and tears at her ropes with all h might.

head_text.subj: IN FRONT OF THE HOUSE / ENTRANCE AREA

text: Martin is standing across from Lindner.  He gives him a  friendly smile.  He shows no apparent signs of the  condition he is in.
Ellen is home.  But she isn't  feeling well.  Can I give her a  message? Lindner takes the painting out from under his arm.
Oh, then I guess that makes my  gift all the more appropriate.   Maybe I'll just give it to her  real quick and be on my way  again. Martin anxiously fingers the hammer in his hands.
Um, I don't think that's a good  idea.  She went to lie down.  I  think she's already asleep.   She's been pretty busy lately  and needs to rest.
Ellen realizes that there is no way she can untie herself But slowly, she manages to loosen one of the bed planks  that she is tied to - bit by tedious bit.

head_text.subj: IN FRONT OF THE HOUSE / ENTRANCE AREA

text: Lindner peeks inside the house past Martin.  He casually  asks:
So, what's wrong with her? Martin is still playing around with the hammer.
Just nerves.  You know, the  move and all that... Lindner realizes that it's no use asking further.  He han over the picture.

Well, then.  Would you please  give this to her for me?  Tell  her, I'd like to talk to her  when she's feeling better.  And  tell her I don't want to run  away anymore.  She'll  understand what I mean.
Sure, I'll tell her. The old policeman walks to his car and climbs inside. Martin smiles and waves him good-bye.
Ellen has finally made it:  She manages to disconnect the plank. She quickly tears the gag out of her mouth and yells as  loud as she can:
(screams)

Help!  Help, I'm in here!  Help  me! She listens if anyone heard her calling. It's useless.  Lindner has already started his car, and  drives off.  The sound of his car engine fades away in th distance. Ellen is desperate.

Martin heard Ellen's calling.  He grins self-consciously  and locks the house door.  Then, he reaches for a board  leaning against the wall.  He takes a nail out of his  pocket and starts to nail the door shut.

Karl Lindner is driving towards Goldmoor.  He is lost in  thought.  Something about the whole situation seemed  strange to him, but he can't put his finger on it. He brakes and looks back toward the house once more (a  moment of hope for Ellen). But then, he shakes his head and steps on the gas pedal  again. The car drives off into the distance.

Ellen gets rid of the rest of her ropes, immediately jump up and races to the door. She checks the door: it's locked.  She peeks through the  keyhole. The key is sticking in the opposite side of the door.  We hear Martin hammering downstairs. Ellen has an idea - an ancient trick from childhood days. There is a book on the bedside table.  She tears out a pa and slides it underneath the door, below the door lock. There is a can of nails on the floor which Martin left  behind.  Ellen takes out a nail and uses it to poke aroun in the keyhole. She pushes the key out of the lock.  The key falls to the floor, but it lands next to the sheet of paper. Ellen pulls the book page in under the door - no key!
(quietly)
Damn. She presses her face flat against the floor and looks  underneath the door crack. There, on the other side, is the key. Suddenly, the hammering stops. Ellen holds her breath...
...The living room windows are all nailed shut.  Martin  prepares to attach the last board.  He reaches into his  pocket - no more nails...!

...The box of nails is lying on the bedroom floor.  Ellen senses that she is running out of time.  She moves faster She pushes the book page under the door again and tries t maneuver it underneath the key...
...Martin comes out of the living room and heads for the  hallway...
...Ellen has it!  She has managed to get the key on top o the sheet of paper.  Carefully, she pulls it in under the door. She picks it up and pushes it into the lock...
...Martin comes up the stairs.  He heads for the bedroom. When he sees the open door, he stops. He hesitates for a moment, looks around. Then, he carefully approaches the door.

Is somebody trying to run away  here?!  Darling, I'm really  disappointed.  How can we ever  have a trusting marriage if you  keep running away from every  conflict? Martin has reached the bedroom door.

You little hardhead, I... At that moment, the door slams into him.  A loud crunch. The wooden door hits him right in the head.  Martin is  knocked to the floor. Ellen comes running out of the bedroom.  She has a wooden plank in her hands.  She wants to make sure that the job done right and clobbers Martin until he stops moving. Then, she sprints to the staircase and runs down the step

Ellen runs to the barricaded house door.  She shakes at t boards, but they are down tight.  No matter how hard Elle tries, it's impossible for her to loosen them. Horrified, she searches for another way out.  She runs to the living room door and looks inside the room...:
...All of the windows are barricaded.  There is no chance to escape!
